importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update, indicating recent developments in the case involving Andrew Stanton and his TikTok threats against ICE agents.
The date when a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor contacted Stanton, leading to a hostile response and further escalation of alleged threats.
The start of federal investigation into Stanton’s online activity, beginning after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center.
The scheduled pretrial conference date in Stanton’s case, marking a key procedural milestone in the legal process.
The scheduled trial date, indicating the timeline for justice being delivered in the case.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Stanton posted threatening TikTok videos, leading to federal charges and an active investigation into potential incitement of violence against federal agents.

keyTakeAways: A Wisconsin man, Andrew Stanton, was charged with threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder a U.S. official after posting multiple threatening TikTok videos advocating violence against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents.

Stanton allegedly called for the shooting of ICE agents in a video, stating, 'If they (ICE) show up to your neighborhood…it’s time we start shooting at you,' and suggested mass shootings as a response to federal enforcement.
Stanton also referenced the September 10 murder of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk, saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks,' which is alleged to be a call for similar acts of violence.

The investigation began in August after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged a query about Israeli military members in Wisconsin and Illinois, prompting federal scrutiny.

Federal agents attempted to contact Stanton multiple times but were unsuccessful until September 11, when a Customs and Border Patrol supervisor directly contacted him and received a hostile response, including an expletive and a request to meet in person.
Stanton pleaded not guilty to the charges and is currently in detention pending trial, with a pretrial conference scheduled for December 1, 2025, and a trial set for December 15, 2025.
The case reflects growing national concerns over attacks on federal law enforcement, particularly in the context of heightened immigration enforcement under the Trump administration.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Stanton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, charged with threatening federal law enforcement officers through TikTok videos.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stanton is the central figure in the case, accused of making direct and explicit threats against ICE agents, which directly ties to the core legal and public safety issues of the article.

namedEntities.name: TikTok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform used by Andrew Stanton to post threatening videos calling for violence against federal immigration agents.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The platform served as the medium through which Stanton disseminated his extremist and violent messages, highlighting how digital spaces can be used to spread dangerous rhetoric.

namedEntities.name: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency tasked with immigration enforcement, which Stanton allegedly targeted in his videos.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ICE is the primary subject of Stanton's threats, reflecting broader national tensions around immigration enforcement and public backlash against federal agents.

namedEntities.name: Charlie Kirk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A conservative political activist murdered on September 10, 2025, whose death was referenced in one of Stanton’s videos.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stanton allegedly encouraged imitating the murder of Charlie Kirk, showing a direct link between real-world violence and online incitement, making the case a matter of public concern about radical messaging.

namedEntities.name: Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal office that tracks suspected terror activity and initiated an investigation into Stanton’s online activity.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The center flagged Stanton’s inquiry about Israeli military forces, which triggered the federal investigation and demonstrates proactive monitoring of online threats.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Homeland Security
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal department overseeing ICE and reporting on attacks on immigration agents.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The department is central to the national narrative of increasing attacks on federal agents, providing context for why such threats are being taken seriously.

namedEntities.name: US Customs and Border Patrol
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency within the Department of Homeland Security that interacted directly with Stanton.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A direct communication between a CBP supervisor and Stanton led to a hostile exchange, showing real-time escalation and the consequences of online threats.

namedEntities.name: John Bradley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Stanton’s attorney, who responded to media inquiries by emphasizing the legal presumption of innocence.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bradley represents Stanton’s legal defense, highlighting the importance of due process and the distinction between allegations and proven facts.

namedEntities.name: Federal prosecutors
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Officials who filed charges against Andrew Stanton based on TikTok content and communication logs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are responsible for initiating and advancing the legal action, framing the case as a criminal matter involving threats to federal officers.

namedEntities.name: US District Court (Milwaukee)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal court where Andrew Stanton was arraigned and where the case is being processed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the venue of legal proceedings, including arraignment, pretrial conference, and trial, which are central to the timeline and process of the case.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, Andrew Stanton, has been charged with threatening federal law enforcement agents, specifically Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers, after posting multiple threatening TikTok videos between August and October 2025. In these videos, he allegedly called for the shooting of ICE agents, referenced the murder of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk, and promoted violence as a response to federal enforcement actions. The investigation began after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged a query about Israeli military forces in Wisconsin and Illinois. Federal agents attempted to contact Stanton multiple times, and a hostile exchange occurred when a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor reached out to him. Stanton, who pleaded not guilty, is currently in detention with a pretrial conference scheduled for December 1, 2025, and a trial set for December 15, 2025. The case reflects broader national concerns over attacks on federal officers and the dangers of extremist rhetoric amplified through social media.
title: Wisconsin man charged after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents, prosecutors say
